Award.AwardTitle: A-infinity structures and derived categories in algebraic geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project is in the field of algebraic geometry with some connections to string theory and noncommutative geometry. Algebraic geometry is a branch of mathematics studying geometric objects defined by polynomial equations and related mathematical structures. In classical algebraic geometry one associates with such geometric objects (called algebraic varieties) a space of functions that is a commutative ring. In this research project, more sophisticated algebraic structures associated with algebraic varieties, such as A-infinity algebras and derived categories of sheaves, will be studied.

The research project will focus on the following topics:
1) A-infinity structures associated with curves and their relation to the moduli spaces of curves,
2) Semiorthogonal decomposition of the derived categories of equivariant sheaves for finite group actions,
3) Cohomological field theories associated with quasihomogeneous polynomials,
4) Sheaves on NC-thickenings and a characterization of Jacobians.
The first project is about some A-infinity algebras associated with curves with marked points. The research will study normal forms of these A-infinity algebras up to homotopy and to relate them to the moduli spaces of curves. In the second project a construction of a canonical semiorthogonal decomposition of the derived category of equivariant coherent sheaves for some actions of finite reflection groups is outlined and will be studied. The third project is concerned with applications of categories of matrix factorizations with computation in the cohomological field theories attached to quasihomogeneous polynomials with isolated singularities. The fourth project focuses on which coherent sheaves on an abelian variety can be extended to a noncommutative thickening, which is a quantization of the Poisson envelope of the sheaf of regular functions. This may lead to a new characterization of Jacobians of curves.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Algebraic geometry is an area of mathematics studying geometric objects defined by polynomial equations in the n-space (called affine algebraic varieties), as well as more general geometric objects, called algebraic varieties, obtained from affine varieties by a certain gluing process.

It is a classical idea that an affine variety is determined by a purely algebraic object, namely, the algebra of polynomial functions on this variety. The large part of the PI’s work revolves around the idea that more general algebraic varieties can sometimes be described adequately by an A-infinity algebra. The latter is an algebra-like structure that has, in addition to the product operation, higher operations with more than two inputs, that satisfy a generalization of the associative law. This approach in recording the geometric information algebraically has been shown to be useful in the context of Kontsevich’s homological mirror symmetry program.

 

The simplest non-affine varieties are projective curves, i.e., one-dimensional algebraic varieties given by equations in the projective n-space. The parameter spaces for projective curves with given discrete invariants, called moduli spaces of curves, play an important role in recent connections of algebraic geometry to physics. One of the results achieved by PI's research is a new approach to the moduli spaces of (possibly singular) curves with marked points. In this approach one does not postulate a priori the types of singularities that a curve is allowed to have, but considers instead natural conditions on the marked points (e.g., require that there are no rational functions with poles of given orders at the marked points). The PI has shown that one class of such moduli spaces appears naturally when describing curves via A-infinity algebras. Applying geometric invariant theory developed by Mumford to this situation gives many new moduli spaces with good properties. These new moduli spaces are obtained by imposing certain stability conditions. The most complete picture is obtained in the case of curves of arithmetic genus one (which are degenerations of the elliptic curves, i.e., of smooth cubic plane curves): here we can determine the types of curves occurring for each stability condition. I used some of these new moduli spaces (for higher genus) to show that the Weierstrass locus in the moduli space of curves with one marked point (which is distinguished by the property that the point is special in some sense) can be contracted to a point by a birational (i.e., generically one-to-one) morphism to an algebraic variety.

 

Other parts of the project are concerned with a related powerful invariant of algebraic varieties, their derived categories of coherent sheaves. Jointly with Lekili the PI found a construction of an equivalence of the derived category of coherent sheaves over a certain degenerating family of curves of genus 1 with the relative Fukaya category of the torus with several marked points. This can be viewed as an enhanced version of the homological mirror symmetry for punctured tori.

 

Jointly with Van den Bergh, the PI studied equivariant derived categories of coherent sheaves which are important invariants of varieties with a group action. Specifically, we studied this category for the action of the group of permutations of coordinates on the affine n-space, and some other similar actions. We proved that the equivariant derived category has a natural semiorthogonal decomposition  whose pieces are equivalent to derived categories of affine m-spaces. The concept of a semiorthogonal decomposition is a standard tool for describing derived categories: it gives a way to understand them in terms of simpler building blocks. We also considered the nonlinear generalization of this picture in which the group of permutations acts on the cartesian powers of an algebraic curve.

 

Another project concerns Fan-Jarvis-Ruan-Witten theory, a version of Gromov-Witten theory in which the target space is replaced by a quasihomogeneous polynomial W in several variables. Earlier, in a joint work with Vaintrob, the PI found a natural way to develop this theory based on the category of matrix factorizations of a polynomial W in several variables. Matrix factorizations are essentially ways of decomposing the scalar matrix associated with W into a product of matrices with polynomial entries. In this project the PI proved that the cohomology classes constructed in this theory have the prescribed dimension, a property that was expected from a different (analytic) approach to the theory.

 

The PI has been advising three Ph.D. students and one postdoc who were working on problems related to the project. He also co-organized a conference within Mathematics and was helping with organizing a math circle for elementary school students.
